entry.title: Trusted Systems and the Perception Factor
entry.summary: Perception Factor Insight: A trusted system is not optional for high PF. It’s essential. When David Allen introduced the idea…
entry.content:
Perception Factor Insight:
A trusted system is not optional for high PF. It’s essential.

When David Allen introduced the idea of a trusted system in Getting Things Done, he wasn’t just offering a productivity trick. He was describing a vital tool for reducing noise; the emotional, cognitive, and logistical clutter that clouds perception.

Ryder Carroll’s Bullet Journal Method adds structure to that clarity. By externalizing thoughts, tracking intentions, and making decisions visible, it becomes possible to reduce distortion and respond to reality instead of reacting to chaos.

Together, these systems do something profound: They stabilize your perception.

🎯 Why Trusted Systems Matter for PF

According to the Perception Factor Framework, your PF (Perception Factor) is how closely your perception aligns with reality. As PF increases, so does the quality of your decisions, relationships, and internal peace.

But this kind of clarity doesn’t happen by accident.

A high PF requires clear inputs, disciplined recalibration, and minimal distortion.
This is not sustainable without an external system.

When you rely on brute force memory:

  • You forget what matters.
  • You become reactive instead of thoughtful.
  • You overpromise and underdeliver.

Each of these increases noise and degrades PF.

🔁 The Cost of Abandoning the System

When people stop using their trusted system, they often:

  • Experience rising anxiety and cognitive clutter.
  • Miss deadlines and lose trust.
  • Feel disoriented without realizing why.

These are symptoms of a collapsing PF, not a lack of intelligence.

📓 Writing It Down Is Leadership

Writing something down — in a journal, calendar, or app — is not a sign of weakness.
It’s a signal of integrity.

“This matters. I will do it. I’m anchoring my intention in the real world.”

When others see you write it down, it brings comfort.
When you follow through, it builds trust.

A visible system communicates responsibility more clearly than words.

💡 Key PF Takeaways

  • Unwritten intentions are unreliable.
    A promise not recorded is already at risk.
  • Memory is performance. Systems are commitment.
  • Noise accumulates when you rely on recall instead of review.
  • PF rises when intentions match follow-through.

🧭 Practical Applications

  • ✅ Choose a trusted system (analog or digital) and use it every day.
  • 🕰️ Capture tasks and deadlines immediately to avoid memory distortion.
  • 🔁 Review and reflect weekly. Adjust commitments with honesty.
  • 👀 Let others witness your system. It earns confidence.

📌 Final Reflection

“People don’t act on truth. They act on what they believe is true.”
A trusted system helps you believe more clearly, behave more reliably, and align your perception with reality.

That is how the Perception Factor grows.

entry.title: Team Trained, Home Misaligned
entry.summary: Scenario A skilled tradesman works as part of a tightly coordinated crew. Over the years, he has developed the ability…
entry.content:
Scenario

A skilled tradesman works as part of a tightly coordinated crew. Over the years, he has developed the ability to communicate with his teammates nonverbally. This saves time, prevents errors, and keeps everyone safe. They don’t need to talk through every step. A glance, a pause, or a tool held a certain way speaks volumes.

But when he goes home, this seamless coordination breaks down. He expects his wife or kids to “just know” what comes next when fixing something together. He grows frustrated. Why are they standing there? Why didn’t they hand him the right tool? Haven’t they seen this done before?

He doesn’t say any of this outright. He assumes. Then judges. Then gets irritated when they don’t respond as if they were part of his crew.

🔍 PF Conflict Breakdown

Element PF Framework Interpretation
Environment Shift From domain-trained clarity to general relational ambiguity
Assumption of Sync Belief that home life mirrors team dynamics
Frustration Trigger Others do not respond to unspoken cues
PF Distortion Projects specialized perception onto untrained individuals

The perception gap is not due to incompetence in others but due to domain transfer error by the trained individual.

⚠️ Noise Factors

  • Emotional Friction: Disappointment masked as irritation
  • Cultural Overlay: “This should be common sense” as shorthand for “Why aren’t you trained like me?”
  • Relational Assumptions: Expecting teammates at home without training or briefing

These distortions reduce PF in the Emotional, Relational, and Self-Perception domains.

🎯 PF-Centered Insights

  1. PF is contextual.
    Clarity in one environment does not automatically transfer to another.

  2. Assumptions are noise.
    When unspoken expectations drive behavior, misunderstanding grows.

  3. Teaching is higher PF than testing.
    If someone is not responding “correctly,” it may not be defiance or dullness—it may be a lack of exposure.

🛠️ Practice Shifts for Higher PF

Behavior to Watch For PF-Aligned Adjustment
Expecting others to “just know” Narrate your thought process aloud
Growing impatient with mistakes Reframe as a teaching moment, not a test of loyalty
Withdrawing emotionally after misfires Reconnect with words, not assumptions
Thinking “they should have common sense” Ask: “Have I ever shown them this step explicitly?”

🔚 Case Study Conclusion

The trained worker’s PF was high in his domain, but faltered when applied to family dynamics. He was seeing reality through a filtered lens of expectation, not through relational clarity.

By recognizing that “common sense” is often a form of context-specific familiarity, he began to shift. He stopped assuming his family was on the same page. He started explaining, teaching, and most importantly—listening.

PF is not static. It must be recalibrated for each environment.

Key Insight:
A high-performing team member becomes a high PF family member not by expecting alignment, but by creating it with patience, clarity, and presence.

entry.title: Reclaiming the Evening Through Quiet
entry.summary: Scenario In a quiet shift, a household made the decision to stop watching television altogether. This wasn’t the result of…
entry.content:
Scenario

In a quiet shift, a household made the decision to stop watching television altogether. This wasn’t the result of a debate or planned initiative. One evening, the screen stayed off, and instead of sitting in front of the usual shows, one partner picked up a book and began to read. The other continued their evening routine; handcrafting in a nearby chair.

There was no announcement. The change simply happened, and the stillness it introduced brought an unexpected peace into the home.

Observed Shifts

  • Reduction in background noise: The removal of television silenced the emotional static that often flows from entertainment, advertising, and news programming.
  • Increase in personal engagement: Instead of reacting to external drama, the couple found themselves having more frequent and thoughtful conversations.
  • Shift in emotional tone: Tension in the home decreased. Differences of opinion were no longer flashpoints. Instead, they became opportunities to work through ideas together.
  • Growth in mental clarity: With fewer interruptions, deeper thought emerged naturally. Ideas were explored that would have been drowned out by constant sound.
  • Restorative calm: The absence of artificial stimulation created a space where both individuals could decompress and reflect.

Domains of the Perception Factor Impacted

Domain PF Movement Notes
Emotional Increased Calm conversations replaced reaction-driven responses
Relational Increased Shared silence led to mutual presence and deeper connection
Cultural Sharply Increased Reduced influence from broadcast media and cultural framing
Intellectual Increased Replaced passive viewing with reading, discussion, and reflection
Sensory/Empirical Slightly Increased Lowered artificial input, allowing attention to rest and reset

Noise Reduction

Noise Source Before After
Television media Constant background noise Entirely removed from the environment
Emotional interference Moderate Significantly reduced
External narrative input Frequent and subtle No longer present
Passive consumption Habitual Replaced with intentional activities

Framework Insights

This situation illustrates how Perception Factor can rise without new knowledge, training, or deliberate philosophical effort. Instead, it grew through the elimination of distortion.

The removal of television didn’t create emptiness. It created stillness. That stillness allowed previously hidden or suppressed clarity to surface. The couple didn’t do anything “extra” to grow. They simply removed a persistent source of noise.

Key Takeaways

  • Reducing noise often has a greater impact than adding complexity.
  • Emotional steadiness increases when the environment no longer provokes reaction.
  • Stillness allows clarity to emerge on its own.
  • Cultural distortion often comes disguised as entertainment or news. Eliminating it can sharpen perception across multiple domains.

Summary

By choosing a quieter evening rhythm, this household unknowingly increased their Perception Factor. The decision to turn off the television removed not only sound, but also the competing narratives, anxiety triggers, and distractions embedded in daily broadcasts.

What took its place was peace, thoughtful dialogue, and emotional space. The clarity didn’t arrive all at once, but it grew steadily, night after night.

entry.title: Common Sense and the Perception Factor
entry.summary: “Use your common sense.” “He doesn’t have any.” “That should be obvious.” We’ve all heard statements like these, but what…
entry.content:
• “Use your common sense.”
  • “He doesn’t have any.”
  • “That should be obvious.”

We’ve all heard statements like these, but what do they really mean? And why do they so often feel like empty scolding rather than constructive guidance?

🔍 What Is “Common Sense,” Really?

At first glance, common sense appears to refer to practical wisdom or intuitive judgment that “everyone” should have. But it rarely functions that way in practice.

Problems with the term:

  • It is assumed, not defined.
  • It often replaces explanation with condescension.
  • It implies universality in perception, which rarely exists.

The phrase becomes a placeholder, a rhetorical shortcut when someone fails to meet our unspoken expectations. It stops conversation rather than inviting understanding.

🧭 Mapping “Common Sense” to the PF Framework

The Perception Factor (PF) measures how closely a person’s perception aligns with reality. Using this lens, common sense reveals several distortions:

Concept PF Interpretation
Common Typically reflects social or cultural assumptions
Sense Often refers to intuition, which varies by clarity of input
Application Gap Projects one’s worldview onto others
Real Outcome Misunderstanding and low-quality judgment

Rather than revealing truth, common sense often masks the presence of unexamined perception.

⚠️ The Illusion of Shared Reality

Saying “that’s just common sense” assumes shared clarity. But PF reminds us:

People act on what they perceive to be true, not what is actually true.

If the speaker’s PF is higher than the listener’s, the gap in perception may be mistaken for stupidity or obstinance. In reality, it’s often a mismatch in input, experience, or emotional noise.

💬 Why the Term Persists

Despite its vagueness, the phrase common sense sticks around because:

  • It feels authoritative.
  • It dismisses disagreement without reflection.
  • It spares us from having to explain or engage.

But none of those habits raise PF. In fact, they lower it by feeding ego, assumption, and tribal language.

🛠️ PF-Aligned Alternatives to “Common Sense”

Instead of relying on the phrase, try asking:

  • What is this person actually perceiving?
  • What assumptions are shaping my frustration?
  • Is there a missing piece of data or context?

These questions:

  • Decrease judgment
  • Increase empathy
  • Create clarity

They shift the focus from blame to understanding.

🔚 Final Reflection

Common sense is often nothing more than common bias.
If perception is shaped by noise, culture, and emotion, then sense will vary person to person.

If we want to live in clarity, we must drop the illusion of a shared internal map and begin verifying our own. PF gives us a better tool than condescending slogans. It teaches us to see.

You don’t raise PF by being clever.
You raise it by checking your lens, not assuming others are broken.

entry.title: Brute Force Memory and Noise Accumulation
entry.summary: Perception Factor Insight: Brute force memory is not a strength, it’s a noise generator in disguise. Many people try to…
entry.content:
Perception Factor Insight:
Brute force memory is not a strength, it’s a noise generator in disguise.

Many people try to manage their lives by remembering everything mentally.
They repeat stories. They circle conversations. They miss details.
This isn’t forgetfulness. It’s friction from unprocessed information.

The human mind was not designed to store everything.
It was designed to process, not retain, complex, unstructured data.

🌀 What Is Brute Force Memory?

Brute force memory is the attempt to manage:

  • Appointments
  • Tasks
  • Promises
  • Plans
  • Emotional conflicts

…using nothing but mental repetition and casual recall.

It may seem impressive, but it’s an illusion of control.
The result is often:

  • Looping conversations
  • Missed deadlines
  • Overcommitment
  • Shaky relationships

📉 How It Affects Your PF

According to the Perception Factor Framework, clarity depends on reducing noise; the emotional, cognitive, and sensory distortion between perception and reality.

Brute force memory amplifies noise by:

  • Flooding the mind with unresolved thoughts
  • Increasing emotional friction
  • Blocking reliable pattern recognition
  • Distorting relational trust

When PF drops, behavior becomes reactive and erratic.
No one can see clearly with 15 browser tabs open in the mind.

🪞 Real-World Examples

  • A manager who says “I’ll remember” but forgets the meeting.
  • A friend who makes promises but never writes them down.
  • A waiter who tries to impress by not using a notepad, but gets the order wrong.

No one is impressed by failure that could have been avoided with a system.

🧯 Noise Signals to Watch For

If any of these appear consistently, it’s a red flag:

  • 🔁 Repeating the same information in conversations
  • ❓ Asking others to remind you of your own commitments
  • 🤯 Feeling overwhelmed but not knowing why
  • ❌ Dropping the ball on small but important details

These are not memory issues, they are PF signal loss due to unstructured input.

🧰 What To Do Instead

Replace brute force memory with a trusted system:

  • 📓 Use a daily log or bullet journal
  • 📆 Track all appointments and commitments
  • 🔁 Review weekly for reflection and recalibration
  • 📥 Capture everything, don’t trust yourself to remember

A clear system is a clear lens.
And a clear lens is how you see the truth.

🔑 PF Principles Reinforced

  • Externalizing thoughts reduces distortion.
  • Looping is a symptom of mental clutter, not insight.
  • Trust grows when people know you will follow through, because you wrote it down.
  • Real wisdom comes from systematic reflection, not memory performance.

📌 Final Reflection

“Brute force memory is what people use when they have no system.
High PF individuals process, review, and clarify — they don’t rely on luck.”

If you want to increase your Perception Factor, the first step is simple:
Stop trying to remember everything. Start organizing to see clearly.

entry.title: Navigating Teenage Turbulence
entry.summary: Context Adolescence often transforms a peaceful home into a chaotic arena. A child who once followed routines and offered affection…
entry.content:
Context

Adolescence often transforms a peaceful home into a chaotic arena. A child who once followed routines and offered affection begins to inject a high level of emotional noise into the family system.

This noise includes:

  • Temper tantrums
  • “It’s not fair” protests
  • Expectations that life should be free of effort or consequence
  • Moments of rage, sometimes escalating to physical outbursts

Without realizing it, the rest of the family begins to walk on eggshells. Communication grows distorted. The teenager feels isolated. The parents feel like strangers in their own home.

This case study uses the Perception Factor Framework to explore how both teenager and parent can emerge from this conflict stronger, more self-aware, and with higher clarity.

👁️‍🗨️ PF Analysis

Key PF Domains Affected

Domain Teenager (Typical Range) Parent (Typical Range)
Emotional 0.30–0.50 (volatile) 0.55–0.75 (strained)
Relational 0.40–0.60 (testing trust) 0.60–0.80 (boundary-based)
Moral 0.35–0.55 (in development) 0.70–0.85 (anchored values)
Self-Perception 0.30–0.45 (fluid identity) 0.65–0.85 (more stable)

The teenager’s PF fluctuates due to rapid development and hormonal instability.
The parent’s PF can suffer under stress if reactions are driven by fear, pride, or fatigue.

⚠️ Common Sources of Noise

Noise Type Teenager Example Parent Example
Emotional Distress “No one understands me.” “Why is my own child treating me like the enemy?”
Overconfidence “I know exactly what I need.” “They’re just acting spoiled and rebellious.”
Cognitive Dissonance Wants freedom but avoids responsibility Wants connection but fears being manipulated
Groupthink Influenced by friends or media personas Influenced by outdated parenting models

🧩 Parent Tools for PF Stabilization

Action Benefit to Parent PF Impact on Teen
Remain calm during provocation Maintains emotional clarity Models emotional maturity
Ask questions instead of lecturing Reduces bias Encourages self-awareness
Set consistent boundaries Decreases confusion Builds structure and safety
Validate emotions, not irrationality Balances empathy and truth Establishes relational trust
Journal emotional triggers Prevents reactive habits Models self-regulation

🧩 Teen Tools for Growing PF

Prompt or Practice Benefit to Teen PF
“What am I feeling and why?” Increases emotional clarity
“What do I want—and what scares me about it?” Builds self-awareness
Observe outcomes of actions Encourages moral development
Hear calm truth from a trusted adult Disarms defensiveness
Make choices with visible consequences Strengthens personal agency

🧠 Shift From Conflict to Clarity

Adolescence is a crucible for developing PF. The volatility is not a malfunction.
It’s a loud, messy recalibration of perception, identity, and reality.

The challenge is that this recalibration happens with imperfect tools. Teenagers often lack:

  • Emotional vocabulary
  • Long-range perspective
  • Experience with feedback loops

Parents must become the stabilizer. If both sides react emotionally, PF degrades.
But if one side grounds themselves in clarity and love, the storm can be weathered.

🎯 Shared Goal

The aim is not mere obedience or peace.
The aim is mutual growth in perception and emotional integrity.

  • The teenager exits this phase with a stronger sense of self and truth.
  • The parent emerges with deeper empathy and refined moral clarity.

💡 Insight

The teenager’s turbulence is not a personal attack.
It is the noise of a person learning to see.

The shift in parenting mindset from “discipline and control” to “clarity and leadership” makes all the difference.
The teen needs boundaries, but more than that, they need a model of clear-eyed compassion.

🔧 PF Summary Table

Role Primary PF Challenge Key Strategy
Teenager Emotional noise and unclear self Validation, structure, space
Parent Fatigue and ego-triggered reactivity Calm modeling, inner work, consistency

🧭 Final Thought

You are not just raising a teenager.
You are mentoring a mind in transition and a heart searching for truth.

Be the lens they haven’t yet built.

Clarity doesn’t mean avoiding emotion.
It means feeling deeply, without distortion.
It means loving without illusion.
It means leading from peace, not pride.

entry.title: When Intelligence Isn’t Enough: Why Wisdom Requires Perception Factor
entry.summary: “Intelligence does not become wisdom without adequate PF.” This may be one of the most overlooked truths in our culture.
entry.content:
“Intelligence does not become wisdom without adequate PF.”

This may be one of the most overlooked truths in our culture. We celebrate intelligence; test scores, credentials, fast thinking but we rarely ask: What direction is that intelligence aimed? Or How clearly is it seeing reality?

That’s where Perception Factor (PF) comes in.

🧠 Intelligence vs. Wisdom

Let’s draw a clear distinction:

  • Intelligence is raw processing power. It’s the speed, memory, logic, and language skills of the mind.
  • Wisdom is aligned perception, emotional steadiness, and moral clarity. It applies truth to life in ways that promote peace, justice, and integrity.

You can have a genius-level IQ and still be unwise, because intelligence without clear perception is dangerous. It’s like handing a race car to someone with fogged-up glasses.

🚗 The Engine and the Windshield

A useful metaphor:

Intelligence is the engine. Perception Factor is the windshield.
A smart person with low PF is driving blind, fast.
A smart person with high PF can change the world.

PF is your ability to see clearly; to strip away distortion, emotion, bias, and ego. It’s not about how much you know. It’s about how honestly you interpret what you know.

That’s why two people with the same intelligence can lead very different lives:

Trait Low PF (0.4) High PF (0.9)
Judgment Biased, reactive Clear, principled
Relationships Transactional, unstable Honest, nourishing
Use of Power Ego-driven Service-oriented
Truth Handling Selective, self-serving Humble, truth-seeking
Legacy Harmful, manipulative Wise, courageous, respected

Intelligence is neutral. PF is directional. Without PF, even brilliance can lead to destruction.

📉 Sophisticated Self-Deception

Some of the most dangerous people in history were intelligent. That’s not a compliment. It’s a warning.

  • Intelligence can rationalize lies.
  • Intelligence can mask bias with elegant logic.
  • Intelligence can defend ideology instead of updating beliefs.

This is sophisticated self-deception; the ability to build complex mental castles out of falsehoods, then live inside them with confidence.

It’s why conspiracy theorists often sound intelligent. It’s why cult leaders are often persuasive. It’s how smart people end up believing and defending nonsense. Their PF is low, but their intellect helps them feel right.

🧭 How PF Turns Intelligence Into Wisdom

When PF is high, intelligence becomes useful, humble, and flexible:

  • It tests beliefs against reality.
  • It welcomes correction.
  • It slows down when emotions run high.
  • It updates its model when data changes.

This is what wisdom looks like: not certainty, but calibration. Not ego, but clarity. Not performance, but perspective.

🛑 Why It’s Not Just About “Being Smart”

We often hear, “They’re so smart, how could they believe that?”
The answer is simple: High intelligence doesn’t protect you from low PF.

In fact, it may make you more vulnerable.

Why?

Because smart people are better at:

  • Building arguments to defend false beliefs
  • Cherry-picking data that fits their worldview
  • Rationalizing emotional or ideological noise

Unless the PF is actively developed, through humility, reflection, feedback, and suffering, intelligence often deepens the distortion.

📍 Bottom Line

Intelligence without clarity is just faster confusion.
Intelligence without honesty is just weaponized ego.

The person with high PF and average intelligence will often live a wiser, calmer, and more meaningful life than someone with high intelligence and a clouded lens.

The world doesn’t just need smart people. It needs people who see clearly, love deeply, and act with moral courage.

That’s wisdom.
And that’s only possible when intelligence is guided by a well-developed Perception Factor.

🔍 Reflection Questions

  • Has my intelligence ever helped me rationalize something I now know was false?
  • Do I revise my beliefs based on outcomes, or only when it’s convenient?
  • Am I surrounding myself with people who challenge my perceptions, or just those who affirm them?

You don’t rise in PF by being smarter.
You rise by refusing to lie to yourself, and learning to see through noise.

entry.title: Voting in the Fog: Political Lies and the Perception Factor
entry.summary: Overview Many voters knowingly return to political sources that have misled them in the past—debates, campaign ads, partisan media—yet still…
entry.content:
Overview

Many voters knowingly return to political sources that have misled them in the past—debates, campaign ads, partisan media—yet still believe they are making informed decisions. The Perception Factor (PF) Framework offers insight into why this happens and how individuals can begin to reclaim clarity in the democratic process.

🎭 Why Sarcasm and Political Spin Lower PF

Sarcasm, evasiveness, and rhetorical flourish are forms of distortion. They increase noise and obscure truth. Within the PF model:

  • Truth = Reality (R)
  • Perception = What You Believe (P)
  • Noise = Distortion between R and P

When politicians or media rely on performance instead of plain truth, they inject intentional noise. Voters who accept this become complicit in lowering their own PF.

Key insight:
You cannot increase your PF while consuming sources that distort reality, even if the distortion feels entertaining, affirming, or tribal.

🔁 Why People Keep Returning to Lying Sources

Several PF-lowering behaviors explain why people return to the same deceptive political sources:

Behavior PF Distortion
Comfort Bias Preferring affirming lies to dissonant truths
Group Belonging > Truth Prioritizing tribe loyalty over clarity
Confirmation Bias Accepting only information that aligns with beliefs
False Positivity Using optimism to shield from uncomfortable facts
Emotional Fog Letting fear, anger, or shame filter perception

“People don’t act on facts. They act on what they perceive to be real.”

🧭 Can We Still Vote With Clarity?

Yes, but not easily. Here’s how a truth-seeker can vote wisely even without a reliable record or media clarity.

👁️ Step 1: Acknowledge the Distortion Field

  • Accept that most campaign speeches are theater.
  • Realize that debates test charisma and spin, not truth.

🧪 Step 2: Seek Behavioral Evidence

  • Has the candidate held public office? Check their actual votes and funding sources.
  • No record? Look for published essays, local initiatives, or long-form interviews.
  • Pay attention to who endorses them, and why.

📊 Step 3: Track Prediction Accuracy

  • Use a Prediction Journal: record claims and test them later.
  • Ask: Has this person been right about anything that matters?

⚖️ Step 4: Embrace Honest Abstention (With Discernment)

Not voting for anyone because no candidate meets a minimum truth threshold is better than voting for a charismatic liar.

Not voting out of despair shows PF collapse.
Not voting out of conscience shows PF clarity.

🔧 Tools to Break the Cycle

PF Tool How It Helps
🧠 Question Loop Ask: What if I’m wrong about this candidate?
🪞 Truth Journal Log moments where a claim felt off and how it turned out
🧪 Track Outcomes Focus on impact, not promises
🗣️ Steelmanning Articulate the best version of the opposing argument
🚫 Media Fasting Take breaks from partisan or performative media

🔚 Conclusion: Clarity Is Harder, But Worth It

Voting under noise is a moral hazard. Participating in a broken system without examining your own distortions lowers your PF and trains you to accept lies as normal.

Clarity is not comfort. But it is peace.

If every voter raised their PF by even 0.1, the political system would shift. Not because politicians became more honest, but because voters demanded it.

entry.title: The ABC Check
entry.summary: Purpose: Use this quick reality check to evaluate a belief, reaction, or situation where distortion may be clouding your perception.
entry.content:
Purpose:
Use this quick reality check to evaluate a belief, reaction, or situation where distortion may be clouding your perception. It’s especially useful when something feels “off,” too easy to believe, or emotionally charged.

✳️ What Is the ABC Check?

The ABC Check is a simple, memorable mental protocol to interrupt distortion and calibrate your perception toward reality. It was inspired by a phrase used to train detectives in the DC Smith Investigation Series by Peter Grainger (read them, they are delightful books):

“Assume nothing. Believe nothing. Check everything.”

In the Perception Factor (PF) framework, we preserve this wisdom as a tool for clarity:

✅ The PF Version: ABC Check

Letter Action PF Purpose
A Assume nothing Assumptions are silent distortions. Don’t act on them, spot and name them.
B Believe nothing Hold beliefs lightly until verified. Ask: “What if I’m wrong?”
C Check everything Test what you think or feel against hard evidence, outcomes, or trusted sources.

🔧 How to Use It

  1. Pause before reacting to a strong feeling, belief, or claim.
  2. Run the ABC Check:
    • What am I assuming?
    • What am I believing without verification?
    • What can I check right now?
  3. Adjust your perception based on the evidence, not the emotion.

🌀 Why It Works

Each letter targets a common source of perceptual noise:

  • Assumptions often bypass scrutiny.
  • Beliefs get reinforced by identity or emotion.
  • Reality checks restore calibration and reduce distortion.

📝 Example in Action

You hear a rumor that someone is talking behind your back. You feel hurt and want to confront them.

A – Am I assuming bad intent without proof?
B – Do I believe this because it fits a narrative I already hold?
C – What can I check—directly, kindly, and clearly—to know what’s real?

You may still confront them, but with more clarity and less emotional fog.

🔄 When to Use the ABC Check

  • Before reacting emotionally
  • When interpreting social or political claims
  • While reflecting on your own thoughts or memories
  • During arguments or high-stakes conversations

⚖️ Final Thought

“Assume nothing. Believe nothing. Check everything.”
—Peter Grainger, DC Smith Investigation Series

This isn’t a rule to live by, but a lens to see through distortion. Use it to test your perceptions, not to become cynical, but to become clear.

entry.title: PF Trilemma Tool: You Can Only Pick Two
entry.summary: “Where there are three desirable outcomes, choosing two means sacrificing the third. That’s not failure, that’s clarity.” This tool helps…
entry.content:
“Where there are three desirable outcomes, choosing two means sacrificing the third. That’s not failure, that’s clarity.”

🧠 Purpose

This tool helps you form and analyze Trilemmas, scenarios where you or others expect to achieve three conflicting goals at once. It’s a clarity exercise used to:

  • Detect distorted expectations
  • Reveal unconscious bias
  • Clarify values
  • Raise your Perception Factor (PF)

🛠️ How to Use This Tool

1. Spot the Unrealistic Expectation

Look for promises, plans, or beliefs that claim: “We can have all three!”

Write them down in this format:

  • [Outcome A]
  • [Outcome B]
  • [Outcome C]

Example:

  • Absolute Security
  • Full Personal Freedom
  • Total Government Transparency

2. Test the Tension

Ask yourself:

  • “Can all three coexist without trade-offs?”
  • “Which two actually matter most in this context?”
  • “Which one am I pretending I don’t have to sacrifice?”

3. Choose Your Two

Make your values conscious:

  • ✅ Keep: [Outcome A]
  • ✅ Keep: [Outcome B]
  • ❌ Sacrifice: [Outcome C]

Explain why this is the best trade-off for truth, clarity, and long-term reality alignment.

4. PF Check-In

Use these PF questions to reflect:

  • Am I resisting trade-offs because they’re emotionally uncomfortable?
  • Is someone else hiding the trade-off to manipulate me?
  • Am I choosing comfort or tribal loyalty over clarity?
  • If I had to face the third loss, what emotion would I need to process?

🔄 Common PF Trilemmas

Trilemma Pick Two Sacrifice
Love, Truth, Belonging Belonging + Truth Love may be rejected
Speed, Quality, Affordability Speed + Affordability Quality suffers
Security, Liberty, Transparency Liberty + Security Transparency drops
